It is true that we as a society often give a great deal of significance to wealth and power, sometimes at the expense of recognizing the contributions of creatives and thinkers who have made enduring cultural and intellectual achievements. 

However, in the case of the Medici family, it is important to recognize that their patronage was not simply about using their wealth to promote their own status. Instead, through their patronage, they supported the intellectual and cultural accomplishments of artists, thinkers, and scientists who might not have been able to achieve their work without their support. 

In terms of celebrating the contributions of artists and intellectuals themselves as opposed to their wealthy patrons, I believe there is a growing movement to do just that. Today, we celebrate artists and intellectual achievements more than ever before, and we recognize that these kinds of achievements can come from all backgrounds and socioeconomic circumstances. 

In conclusion, while it is important to recognize the role that a patron, such as the Medici family, played in supporting intellectual and creative accomplishments of the Renaissance, we should also strive to celebrate and recognize these achievements themselves, without unduly glorifying wealth and power.
